intro: Rhamphicarpa elliotii, commonly known as the Elliot's ghost flower, is a rare and enigmatic plant native to the mountainous regions of Mexico. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, characterized by its aromatic foliage and umbellate inflorescences. The plant is notable for its striking white flowers that appear in clusters, often blooming in the early spring. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered endangered and is found in only a few remote locations. Its botanical features make it a subject of interest for botanists and conservationists alike.
